coredata.dc:title: Eight-point density correlation functions in lennard-jones fluids
coredata.dc:creator: Heyes, D.M.
Wegdam, G.H.
Van Der Elsken, J.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Molecular dynamics calculations of components of the eight-point four-time density correlation function around a probe mulecule in a Lennard-Jones host fluid have been made. This function has important consequences for the interpretation of line broadening and other collision-induced spectroscopic experiments.

Introduction Measurements of the broadening and shifting of the pure rotational lines of HC1 dissolved in dense inert gases hiivc been made in this laboratory in recent years [I] Analysis of the spectra has given some insights into the na- ture of the molecular motion of the host fluid around the HC1 probe molecule [2] and also the probe host poten- tial energy surface [3]. Until recently tlie adopted model for this phenomenon has consisted of an expansion of the fluid dynamics only up to second order or the four-point two-time density correlation function, FPCF [2]. The complete FPCF involves evaluating the number density at four points in space and two points in time, although in this context it is only necessary to obtain a spherically averaged component in which short-range interactions contribute more to the total by the inclusion of a probe host interaction in the ensemble average [2]. There is increasing evidence lliat this treatment is inadequate to reproduce some of the finer details of the spectra [4]. It leads to a consider- able overestimation of the Lmewidths of the low J -> J + 1 transitions. This discrepancy is greatly reduced by in- cluding the fourth-order term, the eight-point four-time correlation function, EPCF, in the expansion [4]. The six- point density function does not contribute for reasons of symmetry. Only the line broadening experiments have provided information on the EPCF so far and this has been restricted to certain frequency combinations in the fre- quency transform as a result of the strict selection rules inherent in this experiment [4]. A complete representa- tion of this function is not therefore available This prompted the initiation of a computer simulation study of the largely unexplored field of the EPCF m the Lennard-Jones, LJ, fluid.
